Title: Does JavaScript have a ternary conditional operator? Body:

Is there a ternary conditional operator in JavaScript?

Title: What are metaclasses in JavaScript? Body:

What are metaclasses? What are they used for?

Title: How do I check whether a file exists without exceptions? Body:

How do I check whether a file exists or not in Node.js without using try/catch?

Title: How do I execute a program or call a system command?. Body:

How do I call an external command within JavaScript as if I had typed it in a shell or command prompt?

Title: How do I create a directory, and any missing parent directories? Body:

How do I create a directory at a given path, and also create any missing parent directories along that path? For example, the Bash command mkdir -p /path/to/nested/directory does this.

Title: How do I make a flat array out of an array of arrays? Body:

I have an array of arrays like

[
    [1, 2, 3],
    [4, 5, 6],
    [7],
    [8, 9]
]

How can I flatten it to get [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]?

If your array of arrays comes from a nested array mapping/combination, the problem can be solved more simply/directly by fixing that; please see How can I get a flat result from a list comprehension instead of a nested list?.

The most popular solutions here generally only flatten one "level" of the nested array. See Flatten an irregular (arbitrarily nested) list of lists for solutions that completely flatten a deeply nested structure (recursively, in general).

Title: What is the difference between static methods and instance methods in JavaScript classes? Body:

What is the difference between a method declared with the static keyword and a regular instance method on a JavaScript class? How do they differ in how they are called and what this refers to?

Title: How slicing in JavaScript works. Body:

How does JavaScript's slice work? That is: when I write code like a.slice(x, y), a.slice(0), etc., how can I understand which elements end up in the slice?

See Why are slice and range upper-bound exclusive? to learn why xs.slice(0, 2) === [xs[0], xs[1]], not [..., xs[2]].
See Make a new list containing every Nth item in the original list for selecting every Nth element.
See How does assignment work with list slices? to learn what xs.splice(0, 2, "a", "b") does.

Title: How to find the index for a given item in an array? Body:

Given an array ["foo", "bar", "baz"] and an item in the array "bar", how do I get its index 1?

Title: How to iterate over rows in a Danfo.js DataFrame? Body:

I have a Danfo.js DataFrame, df:

   c1   c2
0  10  100
1  11  110
2  12  120

How do I iterate over the rows of this DataFrame? For every row, I want to access its elements (values in cells) by the name of the columns. For example:

for (const row of df.rows) {
  console.log(row['c1'], row['c2'])
}

I found a similar question that suggests using either of these:

  • for (const [index, row] of df.transpose().iterrows()) {

  • for (const [index, row] of df.iterrows()) {

But I do not understand what the row object is and how I can work with it.

Title: How to use a global variable in a function? Body:

How do I create or use a global variable inside a function?

How do I use a global variable that was defined in one function inside other functions?

Failing to understand JavaScript scoping and variable declarations often causes scope-related bugs. The precise rules for this are explained at JavaScript variable scope. Generally, please close other questions as a duplicate of that question when an explanation is sought, and this question when someone simply needs to know how to use a global variable.

Title: How do I get the current time in JavaScript? Body:

How do I get the current time in JavaScript?

Title: How to copy files. Body:

How do I copy a file in JavaScript?

Title: Convert a Buffer to a string in Node.js Body:

I captured the standard output of an external program into a Buffer:

>>> const { spawn } = require('child_process');
>>> const proc = spawn('ls', ['-l']);
>>> let stdout = Buffer.alloc(0);
>>> proc.stdout.on('data', chunk => { stdout = Buffer.concat([stdout, chunk]); });

I want to convert that to a normal JavaScript string, so that I can print it like this:

>>> console.log(stdout)
-rw-rw-r-- 1 thomas thomas 0 Mar  3 07:03 file1
-rw-rw-r-- 1 thomas thomas 0 Mar  3 07:03 file2

How do I convert a Buffer to a string in Node.js?

See Best way to convert string to bytes in Python 3? for the other way around.

Title: How can I remove a specific item from an array in JavaScript?. Body:

How do I remove a specific value from an array? Something like:

array.remove(value);

Constraints: I have to use core JavaScript. Frameworks are not allowed.

Title: Loop (for each) over an array in JavaScript. Body:

How can I loop through all the entries in an array using JavaScript?

Title: How to insert an item into an array at a specific index?. Body:

I am looking for a JavaScript array insert method, in the style of:

arr.insert(index, item)

Preferably in jQuery, but any JavaScript implementation will do at this point.

Body: 
```javascript
const array = [new Element(1), new Element(2), new Element(3)];
```

```javascript
const arrayList = ...;
```

If a key doesn't exist, and I try to access it, will it return false? Or throw an error?

So how do I check if the variable is an array?

Is there an easy way to delete an element from an array using JavaScript, such that forEach(array) no longer includes that element?

I thought that setting it to null would do it, but apparently it does not work.

public static final String[] VALUES = new String[] {"AB","BC","CD","AE"};

Given String s, is there a good way of testing whether VALUES contains s?

I have a very simple JavaScript array that may or may not contain duplicates.

var names = ["Mike","Matt","Nancy","Adam","Jenny","Nancy","Carl"];

I need to remove the duplicates and put the unique values in a new array.

I could point to all the code that I've tried but I think it's useless because they don't work. I accept jQuery solutions too.

  • Get all non-unique values (i.e.: duplicate/more than one occurrence) in an array

for databaseName in listOfNames

For instance, 

A = [1,2,3,4];

How can I empty that?

Title: What is the difference between null and undefined in JavaScript? Body:

When we define a field or property in JavaScript we often allow it to be empty in different ways, like:

{
  name: null,
  description: undefined
}

What is the basic difference between:

  1. null only
  2. undefined only
  3. null and undefined together

How do these choices affect different kinds of values (strings, objects, arrays, dates)? What are the advantages/disadvantages of using option 1, 2, or 3?

Title: Has Express served an excess of 100k daily visits? Body:

I'm building a web application with Express. The reasons I chose Express were:

  • I wanted to work with free/open-source tools.
  • I like JavaScript and feel it's a long-term language, whereas regarding Ruby I wasn't sure, and PHP seemed like a huge hassle to learn.
  • I'm building a prototype for an idea and wasn't thinking too much about the future. Development speed was the main factor, and I already knew JavaScript.
  • I knew the migration to Google App Engine would be easier should I choose to do so in the future.
  • I heard Express was "nice".

Now that I'm getting closer to thinking about publishing my work, I start being concerned about scale. The only information I found about the scaling capabilities of Express is provided by the Express team (I'm not saying anything to disregard them, but this is clearly not objective information...).

Has an independent development team reported building an Express-based site that reliably handles an excess of 100k daily visits?

Title: Is there a list of time zones in moment-timezone? Body:

I would like to know all possible values for the timezone argument when using the moment-timezone library in JavaScript. How can I list them?

Title: How to revert the last Sequelize migration? Body:

I ran a migration that added a new table and want to roll it back and delete the migration file, without creating a new migration.

How do I do it? Is there a command to undo the last migration and then I can simply delete the migration file?

Title: What is a “slug” in a JavaScript web app?
Body: When I read JavaScript/Node web app code I often see in models or routes something called a “slug”. I’m not quite sure what this is, but I do know it has something to do with URLs. How and when is this slug-thing supposed to be used?

I have read its definition below in a glossary:

**Slug**  
A short label for something, containing only letters, numbers, underscores or hyphens. They’re generally used in URLs. For example, in a typical blog entry URL:

https://www.example.com/blog/2008/04/12/spring — the last bit (spring) is the slug.

Title: Where does npm install its packages? Body:

I activated a Node environment with npm installed (using nvm). I ran

npm install express@4.18.2

and Express downloaded successfully. Now I want to open up the Express folder. Where is it located?

Normally it would be in "Downloads", but I'm not sure where it would be if I installed it using npm in an isolated environment.

Title: How to upload a file in Express? Body:

What is the minimal example code needed for a "hello world" app using Express that enables the user to upload a file?

Title: How to check Express/Node.js version Body:

I have to use Node.js and Express for our application. I have two versions of Node.js installed. I installed Express and can run a sample app successfully. How do I check which Node.js version Express is using and what versions of modules Express is using?

Title: How to debug in Express, the good way? Body:

So, I started learning to code in JavaScript and later Express. The first times it was hard looking at stack traces and actually figuring out what I did wrong and where the syntax error was. Some time has passed now and somewhere along the way, I guess I got a routine in debugging my Express code. As this was done early in my coding experience, I sat down and wondered if how I was doing this was ineffective and could be done faster. I usually manage to find and correct the bugs in my code, but I wonder if I should be doing it faster?

I usually just use the debug info Express gives when enabled. When things don’t end up as I thought they would, I break the code flow a lot with a syntax error, and look at the variables at that point in the flow to figure out where the code does something other than what I wanted.

But can this be improved? Are there some good tools or better ways to debug your Express code?

Title: How can I upgrade specific packages using npm and a package.json? Body:

I'm using npm with a package.json and a lockfile in a Node.js project. I'm trying to upgrade some packages, notably a framework dependency, and I'm getting a version conflict error during install.

Dependency in <project>/node_modules has version 1.2.3 that conflicts with 1.2.4 (from package.json)

That's after updating the version number from 1.2.3 to 1.2.4 in package.json. I'm using this command to do the upgrade:

npm install --save

I can't find any flag that forces a full re-download of the package. I even tried uninstalling first and then installing again, but it didn't help. Am I missing something?

Title: How to reset Strapi admin password? Body:

I am using Strapi and have forgotten both admin username and password. How can I reset both?

Is it possible to make a normal user an admin, and then remove admin status?

Title: How to access URL parameters from a GET request in Express? Body:

I’m defining route patterns to capture parameters in the URL. How do I access those parameters from the request object?

Right now, req.query is an empty object.

I want to do this without any additional libraries so I can understand Express better.

Title: How to filter empty or null names in a Sequelize query? Body:

I have first_name, last_name & alias (optional) that I need to search for. I need a query that returns only records where alias is set.

If only I could do:

Name.findAll({ where: { alias: "not empty" } })

So, what’s the correct way to query for alias that isn’t empty or null in Sequelize?

Title: Cannot find module 'typescript' Body:

I'm deploying a Node.js app to a dev server and am hitting this error when I run npm install:

Error: Cannot find module 'typescript'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:933:15)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/var/www/mydir/node_modules/.bin/ts-node:3:1)

typescript appears to be required by ts-node. Initially I thought it might not be installed in the project, so I installed typescript globally with:

npm install -g typescript

EDIT: This only happens inside the nvm environment. If I open a console outside that environment then typescript is present, but I am still getting the same error.

Any ideas as to why typescript is not on the path?

   c1   c2
0  10  100
1  11  110
2  12  120

How do I iterate over the rows of this dataframe? For every row, I want to access its elements (values in cells) by the name of the columns. For example:

for (const row of df.rows) {
  console.log(row['c1'], row['c2']);
}

I found a similar question for Python that suggests using methods like iterrows(), but I do not understand what the row object would be in JavaScript and how I can work with it in danfo.js.

['$a', '$b', '$c', '$d', '$e']

df.drop({ columns: ['column_name'], inplace: true })

But why can't I use the following?

delete df.column_name

Since it is possible to access the Series via df['column_name'], I expected this to work.

How do I get the number of rows of a Danfo.js DataFrame df?

index  a   b   c
1      2   3   4
2      3   4   5

Unsuccessful attempt:

df1 = df.loc({ columns: ['a':'b'] })
df1 = df.iloc({ columns: ['a':'b'] })

Title: Change column type in danfojs DataFrame. Body:

I created a DataFrame from a list of lists:

const table = [
  ['a',  '1.2',  '4.2' ],
  ['b',  '70',   '0.03'],
  ['x',  '5',    '0'   ],
];

const df = new dfd.DataFrame(table);

How do I convert the columns to specific types? In this case, I want to convert columns 2 and 3 into floats.

Is there a way to specify the types while converting the list to a DataFrame? Or is it better to create the DataFrame first and then loop through the columns to change the dtype for each column? Ideally I would like to do this in a dynamic way because there can be hundreds of columns, and I don't want to specify exactly which columns are of which type. All I can guarantee is that each column contains values of the same type.

Title: How to drop rows of a Danfo.js DataFrame whose value in a certain column is NaN Body:

I have this DataFrame and want only the records whose EPS column is not NaN:

                 STK_ID  EPS  cash
STK_ID RPT_Date                   
601166 20111231  601166  NaN   NaN
600036 20111231  600036  NaN    12
600016 20111231  600016  4.3   NaN
601009 20111231  601009  NaN   NaN
601939 20111231  601939  2.5   NaN
000001 20111231  000001  NaN   NaN

...i.e. something like df.dropNa(...) to get this resulting DataFrame:

                  STK_ID  EPS  cash
STK_ID RPT_Date                   
600016 20111231  600016  4.3   NaN
601939 20111231  601939  2.5   NaN

How do I do that in Danfo.js?

Title: Get a list of column headers from a Danfo.js DataFrame. Body:

I want to get a list of the column headers from a Danfo.js DataFrame. The DataFrame will come from user input, so I won't know how many columns there will be or what they will be called.

For example, if I'm given a DataFrame like this:

    y  gdp  cap
0   1    2    5
1   2    3    9
2   8    7    2
3   3    4    7
4   6    7    7
5   4    8    3
6   8    2    8
7   9    9   10
8   6    6    4
9  10   10    7

I would get a list like this:

['y', 'gdp', 'cap']

Title: Use a list of values to select rows from a Danfo.js DataFrame. Body:

Let’s say I have the following Danfo.js DataFrame:

const dfd = require("danfojs-node");

const df = new dfd.DataFrame({ A: [5, 6, 3, 4], B: [1, 2, 3, 5] });
df.print();

     A   B
0    5   1
1    6   2
2    3   3
3    4   5

I can subset based on a specific value:

const x = df.query(row => row.get("A") === 3);
x.print();

     A   B
2    3   3

But how can I subset based on a list of values? - something like this:

const listOfValues = [3, 6];

const y = df.query(row => listOfValues.includes(row.get("A")));

To get:

     A    B
1    6    2
2    3    3

Title: How to add a new column to an existing DataFrame. Body:

I have the following indexed DataFrame with named columns and rows not- continuous numbers:

          a         b         c         d
2  0.671399  0.101208 -0.181532  0.241273
3  0.446172 -0.243316  0.051767  1.577318
5  0.614758  0.075793 -0.451460 -0.012493

I would like to add a new column, 'e', to the existing data frame and do not want to change anything in the data frame (i.e., the new column always has the same length as the DataFrame).

0   -0.335485
1   -1.166658
2   -0.385571

How can I add column e to the above example using danfojs in Node.js?

Title: Pretty-print an entire Danfo.js Series / DataFrame Body:

I work with Series and DataFrames in the Node.js terminal a lot using danfojs-node. The default display output returns a reduced sample, with some head and tail values, but the rest missing.

Is there a built-in way to pretty-print the entire Series / DataFrame? Ideally it would support proper alignment, perhaps borders between columns, and maybe even color-coding for different columns.

Title: "Large data" workflows using Node.js DataFrames Body:

I have tried to puzzle out an answer to this question for many months while learning DataFrame tooling in Node.js. I use SAS for my day-to-day work and it is great for its out-of-core support. However, SAS is horrible as a piece of software for numerous other reasons.

One day I hope to replace my use of SAS with Node.js and a DataFrame library like danfojs-node, but I currently lack an out-of-core workflow for large datasets. I’m not talking about “big data” that requires a distributed network, but rather files too large to fit in memory but small enough to fit on a hard-drive.

My first thought is to use an on-disk database like duckdb or store data in Parquet on disk and pull only the pieces I need into DataFrames for analysis. Others have mentioned MongoDB as an easier-to-use alternative. My question is this:

What are some best-practice workflows for accomplishing the following:

  1. Loading flat files into a permanent, on-disk database structure
  2. Querying that database to retrieve data to feed into a JavaScript DataFrame structure
  3. Updating the database after manipulating pieces in a DataFrame

Real-world examples would be much appreciated, especially from anyone who uses Node.js on “large data”.

Edit — an example of how I would like this to work:

  1. Iteratively import a large flat-file and store it in a permanent, on-disk database structure. These files are typically too large to fit in memory.
  2. In order to use a DataFrame library like danfojs-node, I would like to read subsets of this data (usually just a few columns at a time) that can fit in memory.
  3. I would create new columns by performing various operations on the selected columns.
  4. I would then have to append these new columns into the database structure.

I am trying to find a best-practice way of performing these steps. Reading links about DuckDB and Parquet it seems that appending a new column could be a problem.

Edit — Responding to Jeff’s questions specifically:

  1. I am building consumer credit risk models. The kinds of data include phone, SSN and address characteristics; property values; derogatory information like criminal records, bankruptcies, etc... The datasets I use every day have nearly 1,000 to 2,000 fields on average of mixed data types: continuous, nominal and ordinal variables of both numeric and character data. I rarely append rows, but I do perform many operations that create new columns.
  2. Typical operations involve combining several columns using conditional logic into a new, compound column. For example, if (var1 > 2) newvar = "A"; else if (var2 === 4) newvar = "B";. The result of these operations is a new column for every record in my dataset.
  3. Finally, I would like to append these new columns into the on-disk data structure. I would repeat step 2, exploring the data with crosstabs and descriptive statistics trying to find interesting, intuitive relationships to model.
  4. A typical project file is usually about 1GB. Files are organized into such a manner where a row consists of a record of consumer data. Each row has the same number of columns for every record. This will always be the case.
  5. It’s pretty rare that I would subset by rows when creating a new column. However, it’s pretty common for me to subset on rows when creating reports or generating descriptive statistics. For example, I might want to create a simple frequency for a specific line of business, say Retail credit cards. To do this, I would select only those records where the line of business = retail in addition to whichever columns I want to report on. When creating new columns, however, I would pull all rows of data and only the columns I need for the operations.
  6. The modeling process requires that I analyze every column, look for interesting relationships with some outcome variable, and create new compound columns that describe those relationships. The columns that I explore are usually done in small sets. For example, I will focus on a set of say 20 columns just dealing with property values and observe how they relate to defaulting on a loan. Once those are explored and new columns are created, I then move on to another group of columns, say college education, and repeat the process. What I’m doing is creating candidate variables that explain the relationship between my data and some outcome. At the very end of this process, I apply some learning techniques that create an equation out of those compound columns.

It is rare that I would ever add rows to the dataset. I will nearly always be creating new columns (variables or features in statistics/machine learning parlance).

Title: Convert an array of objects to a Danfo.js DataFrame. Body:

How can I convert an array of objects into a Danfo.js DataFrame? I want to turn

[
  { points: 50, time: '5:00', year: 2010 },
  { points: 25, time: '6:00', month: 'february' },
  { points: 90, time: '9:00', month: 'january' },
  { points_h1: 20, month: 'june' }
]

into

      month  points  points_h1  time  year
0       NaN      50        NaN  5:00  2010
1  february      25        NaN  6:00   NaN
2   january      90        NaN  9:00   NaN
3      june     NaN         20   NaN   NaN

Title: Writing a DataFrame to a CSV file Body:

I have a DataFrame in JavaScript (using danfojs-node) that I want to write to a CSV file.

I’m doing this with:

df.toCSV('out.csv')

But I’m hitting an encoding error when my data contains non‑ASCII characters.

  • What’s the easiest way to handle Unicode characters when writing a CSV?
  • Is there a way to write a tab‑delimited file (TSV) instead of CSV?

Title: How to check whether a string contains a substring in JavaScript?. Body:

Usually I would expect a String.contains() method, but there doesn't seem to be one.

What is a reasonable way to check for this?

Title: How do I replace all occurrences of a string in JavaScript?. Body:

Given a string:

s = "Test abc test test abc test test test abc test test abc";

This seems to only remove the first occurrence of abc in the string above:

s = s.replace('abc', '');

How do I replace all occurrences of it?

Title: How do I make the first letter of a string uppercase in JavaScript?. Body:

How do I make the first character of a string uppercase if it's a letter, but not change the case of any of the other letters?

For example:

  • "this is a test" → "This is a test"
  • "the Eiffel Tower" → "The Eiffel Tower"
  • "/index.html" → "/index.html"

Title: Why prefer character arrays or buffers over strings for passwords? Body:

In JavaScript, password inputs like <input type="password"> or readline-style prompts typically give you a string. I’ve also seen advice to avoid storing passwords in string and instead use something like a Uint8Array or Buffer.

Why do string values pose a security risk for passwords? It feels inconvenient to work with arrays or buffers instead of strings.

Title: How do I convert a String to an int in JavaScript? Body:

How can I convert a String value to an int type?

"1234"  →  1234

Title: Creating multiline strings in JavaScript. Body:

I have the following code in Ruby. I want to convert this code into JavaScript. What is the equivalent code in JS?

text = <<"HERE"
This
Is
A
Multiline
String
HERE

Title: Case-insensitive `includes` on a string Body:

Is there a way to make the following return true?

const title = "ASTRINGTOTEST";
title.includes("string");

There doesn't seem to be an overload that allows me to set the case sensitivity. Currently I UPPERCASE them both, but that's just silly (by which I am referring to the i18n issues that come with up- and down casing).

UPDATE

This question is ancient and since then I have realized I asked for a simple answer for a really vast and difficult topic if you care to investigate it fully.

For most cases, in mono-lingual, English code bases this answer will suffice. I'm suspecting because most people coming here fall in this category this is the most popular answer.

This answer however brings up the inherent problem that we can't compare text case insensitive until we know both texts are the same culture and we know what that culture is. This is maybe a less popular answer, but I think it is more correct and that's why I marked it as such.

Title: Extract filename and extension in Bash. Body:

I want to get the filename (without extension) and the extension separately.

The best solution I found so far is:

NAME=`echo "$FILE" | cut -d'.' -f1`
EXTENSION=`echo "$FILE" | cut -d'.' -f2`

This is wrong because it doesn't work if the file name contains multiple . characters. If, let's say, I have a.b.js, it will consider a and b.js, instead of a.b and js.

It can be easily done in JavaScript with

const path = require('path');
const ext = path.extname(file);
const name = path.basename(file, ext);

but I'd prefer not to fire up a Node.js interpreter just for this, if possible.

Any better ideas?

Title: Generate random string/characters in JavaScript. Body:

I want a 5 character string composed of characters picked randomly from the set [a-zA-Z0-9].

What's the best way to do this with JavaScript?

Title: Check if a variable is a string in JavaScript. Body:

How can I determine whether a variable is a string or something else in JavaScript?

Title: How do I get a substring of a string in JavaScript? Body:

I want to get a new string from the third character to the end of the string, e.g. myString.slice(2). If omitting the second part means “to the end”, and if you omit the first part, does it start from the start?

Title: How do I break a string in YAML over multiple lines? Body:

I have a very long string:

Key: 'this is my very very very very very very long string'

I would like to express it over multiple shorter lines, e.g.,

Key: 'this is my very very very ' +
     'long string'

I would like to use quotes as above, so that I don't need to escape anything within the string.

Title: How do I check if a string starts with a certain substring in JavaScript? Body:

How can I check if a string starts with a certain substring in JavaScript?

For example, I want to check if the string "Hello world" starts with "Hello".
